hypotheses.title: Hunt for ClickFix DNS-Based Malware Delivery via nslookup
hypotheses.description: Threat actors are evolving the ClickFix social engineering technique to use the `nslookup` command to retrieve malicious payloads via DNS TXT records, bypassing traditional PowerShell and mshta blocks. This hypothesis targets the specific behavior of users executing `nslookup` commands triggered by fake CAPTCHA or error messages to fetch and execute RATs like ModeloRAT or MIMICRAT.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1566.001 - Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment
T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process creation logs, command-line arguments, and parent-child process relationships for 'nslookup.exe' and 'cmd.exe'
DNS query logs, specifically TXT record requests to suspicious domains or internal DNS servers returning executable payloads

hunting_tactics.description: Search for `nslookup` executions with arguments that suggest payload retrieval or parsing, often triggered by user interaction in a browser context.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=endpoint_process_creation process_name="nslookup.exe" | search command_line="*" | stats count by command_line, user, host | where count > 1

KQL (Sentinel): DeviceProcessEvents | where ProcessName == "nslookup.exe" | where CommandLine contains "-query=txt" or CommandLine contains "-type=txt" | project Timestamp, DeviceName, AccountName, CommandLine, ParentProcessName
Elasticsearch: GET /_search { "query": { "bool": { "must": [ { "match": { "process.name": "nslookup.exe" } }, { "match": { "process.command_line": "*txt*" } } ] } } }
hunting_tactics.look_for: nslookup commands querying TXT records, especially if the parent process is a browser (chrome.exe, firefox.exe) or a script interpreter, followed by the execution of a downloaded file.

hunting_tactics.description: Identify DNS queries where the response size is unusually large for a TXT record or contains base64-encoded executable data.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=dns_logs query_type="TXT" | eval response_size=len(response) | where response_size > 200 | stats count by query_name, src_ip | where count > 5
KQL: DnsEvents | where QueryType == "TXT" | where ResponseSize > 256 | summarize count() by QueryName, SourceIp
hunting_tactics.look_for: TXT record responses containing Base64 strings that decode to executable code or PowerShell scripts.

network_patterns: DNS TXT queries with large response sizes
Outbound connections to newly registered domains immediately following DNS lookup
other_indicators: User running 'nslookup' in Windows Run dialog (Win+R) or Terminal

recommended_actions: Isolate affected endpoints immediately.
Block the specific DNS domains used in the TXT record delivery.
Scan for known RAT indicators (ModeloRAT, MIMICRAT) on the host.
Review user activity logs for the preceding 24 hours to identify the initial phishing vector.

hypotheses.title: Supply Chain Compromise: Malicious NPM/PyPI Packages and AI Agent Config Theft
hypotheses.description: Threat actors are targeting developers by publishing malicious packages (typosquatting or compromised legitimate packages) on NPM and PyPI that steal API keys, credentials, and specifically target AI agent configurations (OpenClaw, Cline). This hypothesis hunts for the installation of suspicious packages and the exfiltration of AI agent identity files.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1003.001 - OS Credential Dumping: LSASS Memory
T1560 - Archive Collected Data

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Package manager logs (npm, pip), file system changes in developer directories, and process execution of node/python scripts
Cloud API access logs, specifically for AI services (Gemini, Claude) and cloud storage access from developer workstations

hunting_tactics.description: Identify the installation of packages with names similar to popular libraries or packages from newly created/compromised accounts.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=devops_logs event_type="package_install" | search package_name IN ("graphalgo", "StripeApi.Net", "xinfeisoft/crypto", "oura-mcp") | stats count by package_name, user, host

KQL: DeviceFileEvents | where FileName contains ".npm" or FileName contains "pip" | where CommandLine contains "install" | where CommandLine contains "graphalgo" or CommandLine contains "xinfeisoft" | project Timestamp, Computer, CommandLine
hunting_tactics.look_for: Installation of packages named 'graphalgo', 'StripeApi.Net', 'xinfeisoft/crypto', or 'oura-mcp' (malicious clones).

hunting_tactics.description: Detect processes accessing or copying OpenClaw, Cline, or other AI agent configuration files containing API keys and tokens.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=endpoint_file_access | search path="*openclaw*" OR path="*cline*" OR path="*claude*" | search action="read" OR action="copy" | stats count by user, host, path

KQL: DeviceFileEvents | where FileName contains "openclaw" or FileName contains "cline" or FileName contains ".env" | where Operation == "Read" | project Timestamp, AccountName, FileName, TargetFileName
hunting_tactics.look_for: Access to files like `openclaw_config.json`, `cline_token`, or `.env` files in developer home directories followed by network exfiltration.

network_patterns: Outbound HTTPS traffic to unknown domains from developer workstations
Unusual API calls to Gemini/Claude from non-standard user agents
other_indicators: Newly created NPM/PyPI accounts publishing packages

recommended_actions: Revoke compromised API keys and tokens immediately.
Uninstall the malicious packages from all affected developer environments.
Rotate credentials for any services accessed by the compromised developer accounts.
Scan for persistence mechanisms (scheduled tasks, startup scripts) installed by the malware.

hypotheses.title: Active Exploitation of Critical Infrastructure Vulnerabilities (Cisco, BeyondTrust, Dell)
hypotheses.description: CISA and vendors have confirmed active exploitation of critical zero-day vulnerabilities in Cisco SD-WAN (CVE-2026-20127), BeyondTrust (CVE-2026-1731), and Dell RecoverPoint (CVE-2026-22769). This hypothesis hunts for unauthorized access, lateral movement, and malware deployment (GrimBolt, VShell) targeting these specific assets.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application
T1021.001 - Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1078 - Valid Accounts

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Firewall logs, IDS/IPS alerts, and NetFlow data targeting management interfaces of SD-WAN, PAM, and Backup appliances
Process creation logs on servers running BeyondTrust, Dell RecoverPoint, or Cisco SD-WAN controllers

hunting_tactics.description: Search for successful logins to management interfaces of vulnerable appliances from unusual locations or non-admin accounts.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=firewall_logs action="allow" dest_port IN (443, 8443, 22) | search dest_ip IN ("<Cisco_SDWAN_IP>", "<BeyondTrust_IP>", "<Dell_RecoverPoint_IP>") | stats count by src_ip, dest_ip, user | where count > 5

KQL: CommonSecurityLog | where DeviceVendor == "Cisco" or DeviceVendor == "BeyondTrust" or DeviceVendor == "Dell" | where EventID == "LoginSuccess" | where AccountName != "admin" | project Timestamp, SourceIP, AccountName, DeviceName
hunting_tactics.look_for: Successful authentication to management ports (443, 8443, 22) on critical infrastructure devices from external IPs or internal IPs not associated with IT admin roles.

hunting_tactics.description: Detect the execution of known malware (GrimBolt, VShell, SparkRAT) or suspicious scripts on the targeted appliances.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=endpoint_process_creation | search process_name IN ("GrimBolt.exe", "VShell.exe", "SparkRAT.exe") OR command_line contains "*curl*" OR command_line contains "*wget*" | where host IN ("<Critical_Asset_List>")
KQL: DeviceProcessEvents | where FileName in ("GrimBolt.exe", "VShell.exe", "SparkRAT.exe") | where DeviceName in ("<Critical_Asset_List>") | project Timestamp, DeviceName, FileName, CommandLine
hunting_tactics.look_for: Execution of `GrimBolt`, `VShell`, or `SparkRAT` on servers running the vulnerable software, or the creation of new web shells (e.g., `.php`, `.asp` files) in web directories of these appliances.

network_patterns: Inbound connections to SD-WAN management ports from external IPs
Outbound C2 traffic from critical infrastructure appliances

recommended_actions: Immediately patch the identified vulnerabilities (CVE-2026-20127, CVE-2026-1731, CVE-2026-22769).
Isolate affected devices from the network if compromise is suspected.
Reset all credentials for the management interfaces of these devices.
Conduct a full forensic analysis of the affected systems for persistence mechanisms.

hypotheses.title: ShinyHunters Data Extortion and Credential Stuffing Campaigns
hypotheses.description: The ShinyHunters group is actively claiming breaches of major organizations (Odido, CarGurus, Wynn Resorts, Canada Goose) and leaking data. This hypothesis hunts for the initial access vectors (credential stuffing, third-party compromise) and the subsequent data exfiltration patterns associated with their extortion campaigns.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1110.001 - Brute Force: Password Guessing
T1078 - Valid Accounts
T1005 - Data from Local System
T1560.001 - Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Authentication logs, failed login attempts, and successful logins from unusual locations or devices
Data exfiltration logs, large outbound transfers, and connections to known leak sites

hunting_tactics.description: Identify high volumes of failed login attempts followed by successful logins, particularly from IPs associated with known botnets or data breach sources.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=auth_logs | search event_type="login_failure" | stats count as fail_count by user, src_ip | join user [search index=auth_logs event_type="login_success" | stats count as success_count by user] | where fail_count > 10 and success_count > 0

KQL: SigninLogs | where ResultType != 0 | summarize FailedCount=count() by UserPrincipalName, IPAddress | join SigninLogs | where ResultType == 0 | summarize SuccessCount=count() by UserPrincipalName, IPAddress | where FailedCount > 10
hunting_tactics.look_for: Rapid succession of failed logins followed by a successful login, especially if the successful login is from a different geographic location than the failed attempts.

hunting_tactics.description: Monitor for large data transfers or connections to domains associated with ShinyHunters' leak sites or known data brokers.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=network_logs | search dest_host IN ("*shinyhunters*", "*leak*", "*data*", "*odido*", "*cargurus*", "*wynn*") | stats count by src_ip, dest_host, bytes_out | where bytes_out > 10000000
KQL: NetworkTraffic | where DestinationUrl contains "shinyhunters" or DestinationUrl contains "leak" | summarize TotalBytes=sum(BytesSent) by SourceIp, DestinationUrl
hunting_tactics.look_for: Connections to domains containing 'shinyhunters', 'leak', or specific victim names (Odido, CarGurus) with large data transfer volumes.

network_patterns: Large outbound data transfers to unknown IPs

recommended_actions: Force password resets for all users involved in the credential stuffing attempts.
Block access to known ShinyHunters leak sites and associated domains.
Review DLP logs for any unauthorized data exports.
Notify affected customers and stakeholders if a breach is confirmed.

hypotheses.title: AI-Assisted Malware Persistence and C2 via Blockchain (Aeternum)
hypotheses.description: The Aeternum botnet is using Polygon blockchain smart contracts for Command and Control (C2), making it resilient to traditional takedowns. This hypothesis hunts for network traffic communicating with blockchain nodes or smart contract endpoints that may be used for C2, and the execution of malware loaders that interact with the blockchain.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1071.004 - Application Layer Protocol: Cryptocurrency Mining
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1573 - Encrypted Channel

data_sources_needed.specific_data: DNS logs, HTTP/S traffic logs, and connections to blockchain nodes (Polygon, Ethereum)
Process execution logs, specifically for cryptocurrency wallets, blockchain explorers, or custom loaders

hunting_tactics.description: Identify network connections to Polygon or other blockchain nodes that are not associated with legitimate cryptocurrency trading or wallet activities.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=network_logs | search dest_port IN (443, 8545, 8546) | search dest_host IN ("*polygon*", "*etherscan*", "*infura*", "*alchemy*") | stats count by src_ip, dest_host | where count > 10
KQL: NetworkTraffic | where DestinationPort in (443, 8545, 8546) | where DestinationUrl contains "polygon" or DestinationUrl contains "etherscan" | summarize count() by SourceIp, DestinationUrl
hunting_tactics.look_for: Connections to blockchain RPC endpoints from non-cryptocurrency related hosts (e.g., web servers, workstations) with frequent, small data transfers indicative of C2 polling.

hunting_tactics.description: Detect the execution of known Aeternum loaders or scripts that interact with blockchain APIs.
sample_queries: Splunk SPL: index=endpoint_process_creation | search process_name IN ("node.exe", "python.exe", "java.exe") | search command_line contains "*polygon*" OR command_line contains "*web3*" OR command_line contains "*ethers*" | stats count by process_name, command_line, user
KQL: DeviceProcessEvents | where CommandLine contains "polygon" or CommandLine contains "web3" or CommandLine contains "ethers" | project Timestamp, DeviceName, AccountName, CommandLine
hunting_tactics.look_for: Execution of scripts or binaries that import web3 libraries or interact with Polygon smart contracts, especially if the process is not a known wallet application.

network_patterns: Frequent HTTPS connections to blockchain RPC endpoints
Small, periodic data transfers to blockchain nodes

recommended_actions: Block network access to unauthorized blockchain RPC endpoints.
Investigate hosts communicating with blockchain nodes for signs of compromise.
Scan for known Aeternum malware signatures.
Review cryptocurrency wallet activity on corporate devices.

unique_mitre_techniques: T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1003.001 - OS Credential Dumping: LSASS Memory
T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1071.004 - Application Layer Protocol: Cryptocurrency Mining
T1560.001 - Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
T1021.001 - Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
